evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal data.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew resists alternative interpretations, as no other factors sufficiently explain the observed coordination failures in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal data.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown aligns with key features of crew interaction failures, including missed cues, unclear role assignments, and delayed responses, as seen in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal case.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observed and documented within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft during the hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identified procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands scrutiny against potential counterarguments or alternative explanations within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal scenario.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal data, reflecting deviations from standard operating procedures.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal data.

assumptions: The absence of warnings and unchallenged actions indicate communication breakdown
The incident context and crew roles are correctly understood from the evidence
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew preventing the incident
If procedural deviations rather than communication failures were the primary cause

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 document lack of effective communication and coordination among crew during the pushback, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpreting crew actions and intentions; possible overlap with procedural deviation

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observed and documented within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft during the hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.

assumptions: The absence of warnings from headset operator or wingman implies a procedural deviation rather than communication breakdown.
The documented behavior of the tug instructor and trainee reflects the actual events without omitted critical communication.
defeaters: If evidence showed the tug instructor received clear communication or warnings from the headset operator or wingman that were ignored, or if mechanical failure was documented causing the pushback beyond TRP, the conclusion might change.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4, H8, H10, and H12 directly document the procedural deviation during pushback execution, showing the aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast barrier without appropriate stop signals or warnings, supporting the claim of procedural deviation rather than communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of communication attempts or failures beyond the instructor's statements; possible ambiguity in crew interactions.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown aligns with key features of crew interaction failures, including missed cues, unclear role assignments, and delayed responses, as seen in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal case.

assumptions: The described behaviors (missed cues, unclear roles, delayed responses) are representative of crew interaction failures
No significant mechanical or environmental causes override the communication breakdown explanation
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely communication and role clarity among crew members preventing the incident
If hardware or environmental factors were primary causes rather than crew interaction

outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in the extent to which environmental markings contributed, but evidence favors communication breakdown

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew resists alternative interpretations, as no other factors sufficiently explain the observed coordination failures in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal data.

assumptions: No mechanical faults were detected or reported in the evidence
Crew communication and coordination are the primary factors influencing the event
defeaters: If evidence showed a corroborated hardware fault causing the failure
If crew communication was confirmed to be clear and effective at the time of the incident

He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal data, reflecting deviations from standard operating procedures.

assumptions: The TRP ground markings are considered key procedural markers for pushback stop points.
Crew roles and qualifications imply expected procedural adherence.
No mechanical or communication failures significantly contributed to the event.
defeaters: If clearer or more visible TRP markers were present and confirmed to be adequate, this might shift the cause towards environmental deficiency.
If communication or coordination failures were documented as primary causes, this would challenge the procedural deviation interpretation.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast barrier, indicating procedural deviation. H8 and H13 highlight limitations in marker visibility and signaling, supporting that the deviation aligns with key features of the environment and procedure. H10 and H12 show crew assumptions and lack of intervention, reinforcing procedural non-compliance rather than environmental cause.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in the adequacy of visual markers and signaling effectiveness

node.statement: The identified procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands scrutiny against potential counterarguments or alternative explanations within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal scenario.

assumptions: No mechanical faults were detected as per the evidence provided.
The procedural deviation is defined as the operator's failure to stop at the TRP.
defeaters: If evidence of a mechanical control malfunction or fault was found through equipment checks or bench tests.
If communication breakdown or environmental factors were shown to be primary causes.

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H8, H12) shows no mechanical fault was detected and the tug instructor controlled the pushback, which continued past the TRP and caused collision (H4), supporting that the procedural deviation withstands counterarguments of mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct mechanical fault evidence is presented; reliance on operator statements and absence of fault traces.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal inspection phase.

assumptions: The TRP marking described applies to the specific aircraft and phase in question.
Crew awareness and training on TRP markings are as stated in evidence.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were adequate and clearly visible to all crew members during the pushback phase, or if the collision was caused solely by procedural deviations without marking issues.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 and H13 directly describe the TRP marking and its size, confirming the environmental/marking deficiency was present and identifiable on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the relevant phase, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the marking deficiency alone caused the incident or if procedural deviations were primary.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency should correspond to the key features and criteria defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal context.

assumptions: The TRP size and visibility described imply a deficiency relative to key features and criteria for the aircraft and context.
No contradictory evidence about marking adequacy is present in the packet.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, adequate, and visible TRP markings fully compliant with criteria for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA, or if procedural errors were clearly documented as primary cause, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7, H8, and H13 directly describe the TRP marking characteristics and visibility issues, supporting that the environmental or marking deficiency fits the key features for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in this context. The discriminator favors environmental deficiency over procedural deviation due to marker adequacy and visibility evidence.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether the marking size and visibility fully meet all defined criteria; lack of explicit criteria details in evidence.

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or exceptions within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal inspection.

assumptions: The TRP marking size and visibility are representative of the environmental/marking deficiency.
Crew statements about signal insufficiency reflect actual marking limitations.
defeaters: If clear, unambiguous, and highly visible markings or signals were present and confirmed effective by multiple crew members, this would challenge the claim.
If procedural non-compliance or communication failures were proven to be the primary cause, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7-H8-H13 shows that the TRP marking was small and visual signals were insufficient, supporting that the environmental/marking deficiency is robust against defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether marking visibility alone caused the incident versus procedural or communication failures

node.statement: Availability of functional communication equipment between cockpit and ground crew during pushback

assumptions: Interphone communication between flight crew and headset operator implies functional communication equipment
Lack of warnings from wingman or headset operator indicates no communication failure
defeaters: If evidence showed communication equipment was non-functional or not used effectively
If there was explicit indication of communication breakdown causing the incident

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. No evidence of marking obstruction or damage.

node.statement: Relevant environmental data (e.g., weather, lighting) was available at the time of the event

assumptions: TRP ground markings constitute relevant environmental data for availability assessment.
No contradictory evidence about weather or lighting conditions is present in the packet.
defeaters: If evidence showed that environmental data such as weather or lighting was unavailable or obscured at the time, or if markings were missing or not visible, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

outcome.uncertainty_source: limited explicit statements about weather or lighting conditions; reliance on indirect inference about marking visibility

children_spec.statement: Crew members were not reachable via standard communication devices during the incident

node.statement: Communication channels were unavailable or disrupted due to technical failures

assumptions: Lack of warnings and assumptions by crew imply communication breakdown
No direct mention of technical failure in communication equipment, but procedural communication failure is treated as communication channel unavailability

If mechanical or environmental factors were primary causes rather than communication failures

node.statement: Crew members were not reachable via standard communication devices during the incident

defeaters: If evidence showed explicit failure or unreachability of standard communication devices among crew during the incident.
If reports indicated that crew attempts to communicate via standard devices were unsuccessful or ignored.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H8, H12) indicates communication occurred via interphone and visual signals but no explicit mention that crew members were unreachable via standard communication devices; no direct evidence of communication device failure or unreachability.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

node.statement: Crew members were physically separated in a way that prevented timely communication

defeaters: If evidence showed crew were physically separated or unable to communicate timely, or if headset operator or wingman were out of communication range.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H3) shows crew were seated beside each other and in communication; H8 and H12 indicate no warnings or communication breakdown due to physical separation, contradicting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in communication effectiveness despite physical proximity

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure is resistant to defeaters in the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal scenario.

Procedural and communication factors are sufficient to explain the event
defeaters: If verified fault codes or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical failure were present
If physical evidence showed control system malfunction independent of operator actions

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 and H12 indicate that the pushback was controlled by the tug instructor and that procedural communication and signaling were insufficient, suggesting the failure was due to procedural deviation rather than mechanical/control failure, thus contradicting the claim that mechanical/control failure is resistant to defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of direct mechanical fault evidence and reliance on procedural and communication observations

node.statement: Communication systems providing environmental or marking information were operational and available

assumptions: TRP markings and clearance described in H7 and H13 are considered sufficient to meet 'operational and available' criteria for communication systems providing environmental or marking information.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 confirms the presence and adequacy of ground markings (TRP) and clearance, and H13 notes the TRP was small but present, supporting that environmental/marking information was operational and available, favoring R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY over procedural deviation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpretation of marking adequacy due to TRP size noted in H13

node.statement: Availability of required pushback procedure documentation to the ground crew

No contradictory evidence about documentation availability is present

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback.
The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H9, H11, and H13 show that the ground crew were trained and aware of the TRP and pushback procedures, indicating availability of required documentation and training, supporting the claim of availability of required pushback procedure documentation to the ground crew.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates mechanical components were missing or physically absent; the evidence instead points to procedural and communication issues (H1, H2, H8, H10, H12) and environmental factors (H7, H13) that contradict mechanical failure as cause.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

assumptions: The absence of warnings from headset operator or wingman implies a procedural deviation rather than communication breakdown.
The documented behavior of the tug instructor and trainee reflects the actual events without omitted critical communication.
defeaters: If evidence showed the tug instructor received clear communication or warnings from the headset operator or wingman that were ignored, or if mechanical failure was documented causing the pushback beyond TRP, the conclusion might change.
